717446f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from 39th Street. At the left is the Metropolitan Opera House. In the centre is the Broadway Theatre, on the site of the future Bricken-Textile Building. Above the theatre, the New York Times Building is nearing completion.
At the extreme right is the Astor Hotel.
1904.

Brown Brothers.

717444f-a.text:
The Metropolitan Opera House, Broadway, west side, from 39th to 40th Streets, showing also 39th Street, north side, from Broadway to Seventh Avenue.  The Metropolitan was built in 1883, and its interior was rebuilt in 1892, after it was destroyed by fire. For some years there was bitter rivalry between the Metropolitan and the Academy of Music, but the Academy could not compete with its younger rival, and at last gave the production of opera,  It is today (1936) the only permanent opera company in New York, although occasional and sometimes successful attempts are made to produce opera at popular price, especially at the Hippodrome.

About 1928.

Ewing Galloway.
No Reproductions.

Neg. #3026

717445f-a.text:
Metropolitan Opera House
P.L. Sperr collection
Rec'd January 13, 1945
Neg. 247

717447f-a.text: Received from Cross & Brown Co., March 1968.

717448f-a.text:
NEW YORK'S OLD METROPOLITAN OPERA HOUSE MAKES WAY FOR OFFICE TOWER

Abandoned by the Metropolitan Opera Company, which gave its 1966-67 season in its new home in the Lincoln Center of Performing Arts, New York's old Metropolitan Opera House now is being demolished to make room for a 10-story office tower.

The new building was designed by the Offices of Irwin S. Chanin, Architect, which over the years has given the city, and the Middle Atlantic Coast from New England to Virginia, great office buildings, urban apartment houses, hotels, legitimate and motion picture theatres, suburban residential communities, a great shopping center and commercial and industrial buildings.

Erected in 1883, the old Metropolitan was the last survivor in a theatrical, opera and concert district, Mostly located south of 42nd Street, which over the years has moved northward by a mile or more with its spine, in general, still Broadway, upon which the old Metropolitan faced.

The new building, to contain about l-million square feet of office and commercial space, will stand on land that still belongs to the Metropolitan Opera Association. It has been leased for a long term of years to the sponsors of the office building, who will pay a ground rent of about $500,000 a year. The ground rent will help meet the operating deficit of the opera company.

Like all other opera companies and symphony orchestras, the Metropolitan Opera Company's box office receipts, even at capacity, cannot meet operating costs.

717457f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, from 40th to 39th Streets. This corner building contains a saloon operated by Kid Mc Coy, of pugilistic fame, the inventor of the justly celebrated corkscrew punch, which is a blow struck in the prize ring, and not a cocktail. This building, and the Empire Theatre, which adjoins it, will still stand in 1936. The corner building, however, will be replaced by the Lefcourt-Manhattan Building, and the Casino Theatre below it, will give way to the Bricken-Casino Building.
About 1900.

International News.
Slide #132
